Description: A souvenir pottery juglet in the form of a human head, probably of Saint Menas. Its neck rising from the crown of the head and a handle from the shoulder. Large nose and wide painted eyes, a dimpled chin, and hair across the forehead and flanking the face, the hair is indicated by vertical striations. The top of the head tapers up to a rim with a double-moulded edge, and the vessel stands on a flaring foot, now damaged. A handle extends from the mouth to the back of the head. Two-piece mould, or made in two parts, with an applied handle. The eyes are painted red-brown and white, and there is black on the mouth and hair; a band around the rim is red and there is red colour on the mouth. It is not clear whether the colours are post-firing pigments or are fired-on ceramic colours. dle. Pale-orange to buff fabric with very fine dark grey/ black inclusions, some red inclusions, quartz and some white grits.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Mercer Art Gallery, Harrogate. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

The fabric resembles pieces from Abu Mina, which appears to be confirmed by the presence of an identical vessel (but different mould-series), identified as an ampulla in the form of St Menas' head and dated 480 to 650 AD (Bailey 2008, 3405; GR 1982,0402.9). Comparanda cited by Bailey have been found at Abu Mena (Kaufmann 1908: 208, fig. 164:7 and 8; Kaufmann 1910: 124, figs 67 and 69; and 129, fig. 72), Alexandria (Pagenstecher 1913: 95, fig. 109:3, pl. xl:6; Kiss 1991: 116; Parandowski 1990: 304, fig. 1:A and D, 6th century AD Kom el-Dikka contexts), Canopus (Breccia 1926: pl. xxxvii:5, dated very late or Coptic), Memphis (Petrie Museum uc48552; Petrie et al. 1910: pl. xliv:170, purchased) and unprovenanced (Ashmolean Museum, Oxford, no. 1872.1078; Fitzwilliam Museum, Cambridge, e.9.1963; Fjeldhagen 1995: no. 200, dated sixth century AD; Gabold 1990: 232, no. 0238; Pagenstecher 1913: pl. xl:8). Earlier dates have been suggested for a parallel from Hadra cemetery, Alexandria, dated to the Ptolemaic period (Breccia 1930, pl.29.6, no.408, Alexandria 22447; Perdrizet 1921, 368, pl.47) and from a tomb near Gaza and from Alexandria, dated late 5th century BC (sic) (Skupinska-Løvset 1978: nos UT 18 and 19). Breccia, E. 1930. Terrecotte figurate greche e greco-egizie del Museo di Alessandria, vol. I. Bergamo. Perdrizet, P. 1921. Les Terres cuites grecques d’Égypte de la collection Fouquet. Nancy.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (IE.12) (Phase 3)
